name: Observer
body:
## Observer.js - a lightweight pub/sub.
Observer is a lightweight pub/sub library that can be used as a single event bus or as a base class for easy communications between objects.

[https://github.com/jimenglish81/observer](https://github.com/jimenglish81/observer)

To install run **npm install** then **grunt**.

## Background
I authored Observer in order to have a lightweight pub/sub library to use while developing decoupled apps. This functionality is available through multiple libraries and frameworks, but I wanted to be able to have a library agnostic one. 

## Usage
To use Observer either create a new instance

```javascript
var observerInstance = new Observer();
```

or use Observer's mixin functionality to decorate an object

```javascript
var myObject = {};
var observerMixin = Observer.mixin(myObject);
```

When possible all methods return the instance to allow chaining for ease of use.

### Subscribing to an event
Subscribe via the **subscribe** method which takes two mandatory arguments and two optional ones.
* **eventName** - _required_ name of the event you wish to subscribe to.
* **handler** - _required_ handler you wish to run when the event is published. 
* **scope** - _optional_ the scope you wish the supplied handler to run in. 
* **once** - _optional_ if you wish the handler to only be triggered once and then immediately unsubscribed. 

```javascript
var observerInstance = new Observer();
observerInstance.subscribe('myEvent', function() {
   console.log('event published!');
});
```

### Publishing an event
Publish via the **publish** method which takes one mandatory and any number of other arguments which will be proxied on to the handler.
* **eventName** - _required_ name of the event you wish to publish.

```javascript
var observerInstance = new Observer();
observerInstance.subscribe('myEvent', function() {
   console.log(myArg1, myArg2); // will log "'foo' 'bar'"
});
observerInstance.publish('myEvent', 'foo', 'bar');
```

### Unsubscribing from an event
Subscribe via the **unsubscribe** method which takes two optional arguments. If neither is supplied it will unsubscribe from all events.
* **eventName** - _optional_ name of the event you wish to unsubscribe from.
* **scope** - _optional_ scope of you wish to unsubscribe from.

```javascript
var observerInstance = new Observer();
observerInstance.unsubscribe('myEvent'); // unsubscribe to myEvent for all scopes.
observerInstance.unsubscribe('myEvent', window); unsubscribe to myEvent for handlers in the window scope.
observerInstance.unsubscribe(null, window); unsubscribe to all events for handlers in the window scope.
observerInstance.unsubscribe(); // unsubscribe to all events in all scopes
```

## Advanced Usage

### Event bubbling
Observer events can bubble if needed, but only if it is enabled via a builder method. Bubbling can be stopped if any of the handlers return false similar to DOM events with jQuery.
Important - events that bubble must be separated by a ':'

```javascript
var observerInstance = new Observer();
observerInstance.withEventBubbling();
observerInstance.subscribe('myEvent', handler);
observerInstance.subscribe('myEvent:myChildEvent', handlerThatDoesNotReturnFalse);
observerInstance.publish('myEvent:myChildEvent', 'myArg'); // both handlers will be called with 'myArg'

observerInstance.subscribe('myEvent:myChildEvent', handlerThatDoesReturnFalse);
observerInstance.publish('myEvent:myChildEvent', 'myArg'); // only listeners to myChildEvent called.
```

### Checking if an event has a listener
This can be done quite easily via the **hasListeners** method. It optionally takes one eventName argument. If it is left out then the method will return if the observer has any listeners. The returned value is a Boolean.
* **eventName** - _optional_ name of the event you wish to check for listeners.

```javascript
var observerInstance = new Observer();
observerInstance.hasListeners(); // false.
observerInstance.subscribe('myEvent', handler);
observerInstance.hasListeners('myEvent'); // true.
```

Any issues please contact Jim English (@jimenglish81) or submit a pull request.
